Notes: Environmental Tolerances: Does very poorly under low-N conditions like most grasses.
Notes: Basic Agronomics: Dry matter highly dependent on planting and termination date and precipitation. For grazing purposes, restrict to 75% of total ration or mixing with a grass is recommended. High glucosinolates interfer with mineral metabolism. Nitrate poisoning is possible if fed to livestock.
Soil Drainage: ["Somewhat poorly drained","Moderately well drained","Well drained","Well drained muck"]
Notes: Planting: In RI we found that 15 lbs/acre gave more biomass and better weed suppression when using mustard as a summer cover crop
Notes: Termination [Goal: Method: Timing: if using as biofumigant terminate at pod fill (seed formed but still green) by flail mowing followed immediately by incorporation. Multiple species are called "mustard" - susceptibility to freezing in vegetative state varies widely.
Notes: Weeds: Many Brassicas have hard seed; Can bolt under certain conditions and  become a serious weed if allowed to go to seed.
Notes: Disease & Non-Weed Pests: Many Brassicas have hard seed; Can bolt under certain conditions and  become a serious weed if allowed to go to seed. Host for root-lesion nematode (P. penetrans).
Notes: Contains high levels of glucosinulates. Do not feed to livestock.
